Chemical Geology

Volume 334, 12 December 2012, Pages 266-279

Mantle source heterogeneity for South Tyrrhenian magmas revealed by Pb isotopes and halogen contents of olivine-hosted melt inclusions

Author links open overlay panel, , , , , ,
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chemgeo.2012.10.033Get rights and content

Abstract

Nineteen olivine-hosted melt inclusions from seven volcanoes (Etna, Stromboli, Vulcano, Ustica, Alicudi, Marsili and Vavilov) from the southern Italy region were analyzed for abundances of major, trace, and volatile elements, along with Pb isotope ratios (207Pb/206Pb, 208Pb/206Pb and 206Pb/204Pb). The systematics of primary volatile (in particular F and Cl) compositions and Pb isotopes identify three main geochemically distinct mantle sources for this region: (1) a component with radiogenic Pb (207Pb/206Pb = 0.780) and low volatile element abundances typified by the Etnean melt inclusions, (2) a component with moderately radiogenic Pb (207Pb/206Pb = 0.798) and high volatile abundance mainly associated with Sommata magmas, and (3) a component with moderate volatile abundances associated with a MORB-like 207Pb/206Pb (0.830).

The variation of F/Nd and Pb isotopes among the southern Italy melt inclusions reflects mixing between a slightly modified depleted mantle (DMMâ€“EMII mixture) and radiogenic (HIMU-like) mantle components expressed in Pb isotope space, superimposed by slab-derived metasomatic components represented by F/Nd (F/Nd > 30).

Highlights

â–º We measured in situ Pb isotopes, H2O, CO2, F, Cl and S in olivine-hosted melt inclusions. â–º There is a HIMU-like radiogenic Pb source under South Tyrrhenian volcanoes. â–º F/Ndâ€“Cl/Nb systematics rule out recently subducted AOC as for this radiogenic Pb source. â–º Low F/Nd results from slab dehydration. â–º The fluid, coming from the slab, metasomatizes and raises F/Nd of the mantle wedge.

1. Introduction

Transfer of volatile elements from subducting slab to mantle beneath arc volcanoes through the mantle wedge, triggers partial melting and ultimately produces island arc lavas. However, due to scarcity of arc lavas representing primary compositions, much of the evidence for this coupled volatile enrichment/flux melting model has been derived indirectly from the compositional systematics of the end products, i.e. erupted volcanic rocks with evolved compositions. Thus, in essence, the models of arc magma genesis often depend intimately on the interpretation of compositional systematics that have been influenced by shallow-level contamination and differentiation processes. Alternatively, silicate melt inclusions trapped in early-formed phenocrysts during their growth can partly overcome this difficulty; olivine, the first liquidus phase in many basalts, may isolate early liquids which can provide direct information about primary magmas.

Given the key role of volatiles in arc magma genesis, and their role in the explosive character of arc volcanoes, the abundance of volatile elements in primary arc magma is fundamentally important forrefining melting models in subduction zones. However, the ability of melt inclusions within minerals to preserve information on the instantaneous volatile content of magmas depends strongly on retention of how efficiently the volatile species is retained. For example, H2O can diffuse out of olivine-hosted inclusions at magma chamber conditions (e.g. Hauri, 2002, Portnyagin et al., 2008, Chen et al., 2011, Gaetani et al., 2012). Similarly, sulfur can be lost via degassing, when melt inclusions are formed under near surface conditions (< 170 MPa according to MÃ©trich et al., 2010). Since CO2 probably degasses before crystallization of the host-olivine, preservation of primitive CO2 content in melt inclusions is unlikely (MÃ©trich and Wallace, 2008, Moore, 2008). On the contrary, due to their higher solubility in mafic melts compared with CO2 or H2O (Webster, 2004) and their late degassing during magma ascent (Spilliaert et al., 2006a, Spilliaert et al., 2006b), F and Cl abundances often remain unchanged in melt inclusions, while H2O, CO2, and S show depletion trends (e.g. Vigouroux et al., 2008). Thus, the halogens have the potential to preserve their primitive abundances in the inclusions (Le Voyer et al., 2010, MÃ©trich et al., 2010).

F and Cl play a key role in identifying slab inputs to the mantle wedge. For example, in olivine-hosted melt inclusions from Mount Shasta (Cascades volcanic arc), the F/Cl ratio identifies two fluid components involved in magma genesis (Le Voyer et al., 2010), while only one fluid component is identified using cation trace element (Ba, Sr) correlations (e.g. Le Voyer et al., 2010) and boron isotope compositions (e.g. Rose et al., 2001). Therefore, in this study, we discuss the volatile characteristics of the primitive magmas and their source mantle geochemistry mainly through the F and Cl concentrations of olivine-hosted melt inclusions.

In situ analyses of Pb isotope compositions by secondary ion mass-spectrometry (SIMS) have demonstrated the utility of Pb isotope information found in olivine-hosted melt inclusions (Saal et al., 1998, Kobayashi et al., 2004, Yurimoto et al., 2004, Saal et al., 2005, Schiavi et al., 2011). Among many conclusions, these studies have shown that the melt inclusions exhibit a much wider spectrum of isotope compositions than their host lavas, and magmas with different isotopic compositions may exist in the volcanic plumbing system before melt aggregation. Although the precision of the isotopic ratio measured in situ by SIMS is inferior to that of the conventional bulk-wet chemistry techniques, primitive trace element abundances, including volatile elements, and Pb isotope ratio data can be measured in primitive melt inclusions preserved in early-formed minerals. This provides new geochemical information which is unaffected by shallow-level crustal modification processes, such as mixing and crystal fractionation. This has potential for investigating subduction-related magmas, when the sources of primary arc-magmas and slab fluxes have contrasting Pb isotope signatures. Thus, a combination of in situ analyses of Pb-isotopes and volatile element abundances provides unique insights into the source characteristics and origin of arc magmas.

The origin of the lavas in the Italian peninsula with respect to the relative importance of crustal contamination and mantle heterogeneity is often debated (e.g. Conticelli et al., 2007). In particular, the geodynamic setting of the southern Italy region has drawn the attention of many investigators: a predominantly calc-alkaline magmatism, with some potassic affinities, is found in the Aeolian Islands (e.g., Stromboli, Alicudi and Sommata, Fig. 1), Na-alkaline magmatism dominates the nearby eastern Sicily volcanoes (e.g., Mount Etna and its older counterpart Aci Castello) and Ustica Island, and MORB-type magmas were sampled in the back-arc basin region (e.g., Vavilov). For this study, we have analyzed selected olivine-hosted melt inclusions from volcanoes located in southern Italy, chosen on the basis of their whole rock variability in Pb isotope compositions, and the extensive descriptions available for the volcanoes, the lava flows and host rocks. We report data on lithophile and volatile trace element abundances and Pb isotope ratios all measured in the same inclusions. The ratios of Pb isotopes of primitive melt inclusions correlate with normalized F and Cl abundances, and suggest the presence of dry, subduction-processed, crustal material in the source of Etna and Ustica.

2. Sample description

Mount Etna and Ustica are on islands adjacent to the Quaternary Aeolian island arc where sinking slab dips 50â€“60Â° beneath the Tyrrhenian Sea (Fig. 1). The eastward migration of the Tyrrhenianâ€“Appenines subduction system and the related back-arc extension resulted in the formation of two small oceanic basins (Vavilov and Marsili basins), bounded to the east by the Aeolian volcanic arc. The 8 selected samples (Fig. 1) are basalts containing magnesian olivine crystals (70â€“89 mol% forsterite content expressed as Fo70â€“89 hereafter). They can be classified into three groups based on their tectonic setting: (1) Etna and Ustica, (2) Aeolian volcanic arc including the Sommata, Alicudi and Stromboli volcanoes and (3) Marsili and Vavilov bark-arc samples. Their geochemistry and petrology have been described previously elsewhere (e.g. Cinque et al., 1988, Beccaluva et al., 1990, Clocchiatti et al., 1992, Peccerillo and Wu, 1992, Hornig-Kjarsgaard et al., 1993, Gioncada et al., 1998, Trua et al., 2002, Spilliaert et al., 2006b) and only a brief summary is given here.

Etnean samples include tholeiitic hyaloclastites from the Aci Castello series, which outcrop at the southeast periphery of the volcano and represent samples of the oldest Etnean volcanics so far identified (520 Â± 40 kyr BP; Gillot et al., 1994), and present-day trachybasalt scoria from the 2002 flank eruptions. In the Aci Castello samples, the studied melt inclusions are hosted by olivines of Fo83 and Fo85, values that are consistent with previous Aci Castello studies (Kamenetsky and Clocchiatti, 1996, Clocchiatti et al., 1998), whereas 2002 Etna olivines are less forsteritic ( Fo72 and Fo82). The low Fo olivines (similar to the olivine containing melt inclusion E1, Table 1) have been described as resulting from late-stage magma crystallisation during shallow open-conduit degassing (MÃ©trich et al., 2004). The high Fo82 olivines (similar to the olivine containing melt inclusion E2, Table 1) have already been described for the 2002 Etna eruption and are attributed to a closed system ascent of a batch of more primitive basaltic magma (Spilliaert et al., 2006b).

Ustica olivine phenocrysts (Fo79, 82, Table 1) are from basaltic hyaloclastites from the Quaternary submarine series of Punta dello Spalmatore, west of Ustica island, where erupted lavas range in composition from hawaiites to mugearites (Cinque et al., 1988).

The calc-alkaline series samples of the Aeolian arc are from Vulcano, Alicudi and Stromboli islands. On Vulcano island, olivine phenocrysts (Fo87â€“90, Table 1) are found in scoriae from La Sommata pyroclastic cone, erupted ~ 50 kyr ago (Gioncada et al., 1998). Most of the La Sommata erupted products belong to the shoshonitic series. Alicudi is a composite volcano made up predominantly of lavas and minor pyroclastic rocks (Peccerillo et al., 2004); olivine phenocrysts (Fo85â€“89, Table 1) are found in calc-alkalic basalts. Alicudi rock ages range from 90 to ~ 30 ka and represent the youngest activity in the western Aeolian arc (Gillot and Villari, 1980).

At Stromboli, olivine phenocrysts (Fo70â€“83, Table 1) are collected from a pyroclastic fall deposit of the lower and middle Vancori unit, dated at ~ 26 ky BP (Gillot and Keller, 1993, Keller et al., 1993). The Vancori volcanics form a continuous sequence of shoshonitic character from basalts to trachytes (Hornig-Kjarsgaard et al., 1993). There is a consensus (Bertagnini et al., 2008) that two magma types are involved in the present-day activity on Stromboli: (1) a low porphyritic (LP), volatile-rich basaltic magma residing in the volcanic plumbing system (7 to 9.5 km below the summit vents, i.e. 190 to 280 MPa; Aiuppa et al., 2010) and (2) a volatile-poor shoshonitic basalt (the HP magma) that feeds the normal Stromboli activity. The transition mechanism from LP to HP must take place in the plumbing system most likely at a depth range around 2 to 4 km (50â€“100 MPa) in order to explain the extensive H2O loss (< 1.5 wt.% H2O remaining). Based on this, S2 (Table 1) is interpreted as a melt inclusion (from LP magma) that lost some of its H2O, whereas S1 (Table 1) would be a melt inclusion from a later, more evolved stage, representing the beginning of a shoshonitic magma (HP). S1 and S2 thus represent different stages of the transition of the Stromboli magma.

In the back-arc basin, at Marsili, the largest seamount in the Tyrrhenian Sea, olivine phenocrysts (Fo89) were found in basalt and basaltic andesite samples dregded from the back-arc basin. Detailed petrographic and geochemical investigations of lavas from Marsili volcano are reported by Trua et al., 2002, Trua et al., 2007, Trua et al., 2010. These studies reveal that most of the volcano is composed of island-arc lavas varying from basalts to basaltic andesites.

Olivine phenocrysts from the Vavilov ocean-floor back-arc basin range in forsterite content from Fo82 to Fo89 (Table 1). Lavas from the Vavilov back-arc basin show general petrogenetic affinities ranging from transitional MORB (Site 655 and DSDP Site 373) to calc-alkaline and high-K calc-alkaline orogenic basalts (Sites 650 and 651; Beccaluva et al., 1990).

All of the selected inclusions are glassy, naturally quenched during eruption, and did not require laboratory homogenization. Post-entrapment reactions that occurred inside the inclusions are restricted to slight overgrowth of host olivine on inclusion walls. Correction for this crystallization is made by using the Feâ€“Mg exchange coefficient between coexisting olivine and basaltic liquid KdFeâ€“Mg (Roeder and Emslie, 1970, Toplis, 2005) and by adding increments of equilibrium olivine to the melt until the calculated olivine reached the composition of the host olivine, following the procedure in Laubier et al. (2007). In all cases calculated amounts of olivine crystallized on the inclusion walls were less than 18 wt.%. Note that Mgâ€“Fe2 + exchange between melt inclusion and olivine can result in a significant decrease in FeO and increase in MgO in the melt inclusions (i.e., the â€œiron lossâ€ effect; Danyushevsky et al., 2000). Anomalously high KdFeâ€“Mg values between the melt inclusion and the host olivine, which would result from â€œiron lossâ€, are not observed, thus making significant correction for â€œiron lossâ€ is unnecessary.

3. Microanalyses

3.1. Sample preparation

Selected olivine grains containing 19 melt inclusions overall were firstly embedded in a one-inch epoxy mount where the melt inclusions were exposed by polishing down the olivine on silicon carbide paper with water, then on polishing discs with successively 6 Î¼m, 3 Î¼m and 1 Î¼m diamond pastes. All polished inclusion-bearing olivines were removed from the epoxy with a soldering iron and pressed into high-purity indium encrusted in an one-inch mount. Lastly, the mount was polished with a 0.25 Î¼m alumina paste for 5 min, to erase all scratches from the glass surface. Then the mount was washed in an ultrasonic bath in pure ethanol for 10 min followed by 10 min in distilled water, and dried in an oven at 100 Â°C for at least 24 h before final gold-coating. Prior to analysis, every sample mount was placed for at least 12 h under high vacuum (low 10âˆ’ 8 Torr) to reduce surface adsorption of vapor and other volatile elements.

After SIMS analyses, the gold coating was removed by polishing with 0.25 Î¼m alumina powder. A carbon coating was applied to the surface after it was washed clean. Since electron microprobe analysis requires carbon-coating on the mount, the analyses were conducted after ion probe CO2 concentration measurements in order to avoid surface contamination by carbon.

3.2. Monocollection measurements of volatile elements by SIMS

The analyses were carried out at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (USA) using a monocollector Cameca IMS 1280 ion probe. We used a Cs+ primary beam with a current of 1.5 nA. The electron gun was used to avoid charging of the sample surface. The sample was pre-sputtered for 3 min with a 30 Ã— 30 Î¼m square raster, and analyses were performed on the central 15 Ã— 15 Î¼m area, centered in the rastered area by a mechanical aperture placed at the secondary ion image plane. The instrument was operated with a mass resolving power of 6600, allowing complete discrimination of interferences (34SH on 35Cl, 17O on 16OH, 29SiH on 30Si and 31PH on 32S). We used a critical illumination method. A 400-Î¼m contrast aperture was used and the energy slit opening was Â± 30 eV. We collected the signal for 12C(10 s), 16O1H(10 s), 19F(5 s), 30Si(5 s, reference mass), 32S(5 s) and 35Cl(5 s) (counting times in parenthesis), with a 2 to 4 s waiting time after each switch of the magnet. This cycle was repeated 10 times during each analysis. Including pre-sputter time, each measurement lasted approximately 15 min.

The concentrations were determined using calibration curves obtained by measuring a set of natural basaltic glasses during the same session and under the same analytical conditions (Rose-Koga et al., 2008; Supplementary Table S5 in Helo et al., 2011) with a large range of concentrations in volatile elements overlapping most of our samples' concentrations (H2O from 0.05 to 2.49 wt.%; CO2 from 88 to 237 ppm, F from 90 to 997 ppm, S from 38 to 1640 ppm and Cl from 45 to 2914 ppm, Fig. 2). The correction factors for the relative ionization efficiencies were calculated, with this set of standards, by linear regression. The maximum uncertainties, taking into account the reproducibility over 10 cycles of analyses and the uncertainties on the regression of the calibration line, were less than 5% for H2O, 15% for CO2, and 10% for Cl, F and S.

3.3. Multicollection measurements of Pb isotopes by SIMS

Pb isotopes were measured at the Swedish Museum of Natural History and Nordic Center for Earth Evolution (NORDSIMS, Sweden) on a Cameca IMS 1280 ion probe with a multi-collection system. Samples were sputtered with a focussed O2- primary beam of 8 nA, with a primary accelerating voltage of 13 kV. After a 90 s pre-sputter with a 25 Ã— 25 Î¼m raster, the raster was stopped during analyses. We used a Kohler illumination method. This resulted in a 15 Î¼m flat-bottomed pit centered in the 25 Î¼m square raster-cleaned area. Secondary positive ions were accelerated at 10 kV and analyzed at mass resolution of 4800. All mass interferences were resolved at this mass resolution. The size of the field aperture was set at 4000 Î¼m, and the contrast aperture at 400 Î¼m. The centered energy window was adjusted to Â± 45 eV. The multicollection system was composed of 5 ion-counting electron multipliers set on moveable trolleys (L2, L1, C, H1 and H2). The detection array was configured to measure 204Pb+ in the electron multiplier set on the trolley position L2, 206Pb+ in L1, 207Pb+ in C (placed on the ion optical axis) and 208Pb+ in H1. The measurements were conducted over 40 to 120 cycles with a 20 s counting time for each mass and a deadtime correction of 60 ns. A measurement lasted approximately 20 min for 40 cycles. With this setting, the sensitivity on 208Pb is 19 cts/ppm/nA. We have extensively evaluated the inter-calibration and reliability of the multi-collection system, details of which are given in Appendix A.

Precisions of 204Pb based ratios are inadequate for distinguishing geochemical sources. It should be noted, however, that our in-run precision of 206Pb/204Pb ranges from 0.04 to 0.41 (2Ïƒ, corresponding to 0.2â€“2.1% relative standard deviation) for Pb concentrations of 13 to 2.4 ppm, respectively. This is an improvement over previous Pb isotope data obtained by a mono-collector SIMS (estimated Pb concentrations range from 5 to 25 ppm, corresponding precisions range from 1.6 to 0.5% relative; Saal et al., 2005). The precision recently achieved by laser ablation coupled with a multicollector ICPMS is comparable to what is achieved here (Paul et al., 2011): 206Pb/204Pb precision ranging from 0.04 to 0.54 (0.2â€“2.5% relative) for melt inclusions from the same study area as that of Saal et al. (2005).

In conclusion, the in-run relative standard errors (2Ïƒ) for 207Pb/206Pb and 208Pb/206Pb were less than 0.4% and 0.3% respectively. The repeated 207Pb/206Pb measurements of the GOR132g glass standard (20 ppm Pb, Jochum et al., 2006) yielded a 0.15% relative variation (1Ïƒ of the distribution). The in-run relative standard errors (2Ïƒ) for 206Pb/204Pb and 208Pb/204Pb are less than 1.3% for the samples with 10 ppm Pb or more. Overall, a multicollection system can attain approximately 40% improvement of precision firstly through improved counting efficiency (i.e., one versus four detectors), and secondly through improved correlation among signals (i.e., standard deviations of ratios are smaller).

3.4. Major and trace element abundance measurements

Major element concentrations in the melt inclusions and host olivines were measured by an electron microprobe (Cameca SX100) at the Laboratoire Magmas et Volcans. The electron beam conditions were set to 15 kV accelerating voltage, 8 nA current, and the beam size was chosen between 5 and 20 Î¼m, depending on the size of the inclusion. No effect of alkali loss was detected under these conditions (e.g. Le Voyer et al., 2010).

Trace element abundances in these melt inclusions were determined in two ways. The first measurements (10B, 88Sr, 89Y, 90Zr, 93Nb, 138Ba, 139La, 140Ce, 142Nd, 147Sm, 149Sm, 153Eu, 163Dy, 174Yb) were carried out at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI, MA, USA) using a Cameca IMS 3f ion probe. We used a 10 kV accelerating voltage with an Oâˆ’ primary beam and a 6 nA intensity, a 4.5 kV secondary accelerating voltage, a âˆ’ 90 V offset with a Â± 30 eV window, a mass resolving power of 300 and a projected beam size ranging from 10 to 20 Î¼m. The second measurements were carried out at the Laboratoire Magmas et Volcans using a laser ablation system (193 nm Excimer Resonetics M-50E laser ablation system) coupled with an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer, Agilent 7500 cs (LA-ICPMS). Analyses were made with a laser pulse frequency of 2 Hz with a maximum output energy of 6 mJ. Twenty masses were collected with an integration time of 20 ms per mass: 47Ti, 85Rb, 88Sr, 89Y, 90Zr, 93Nb, 137Ba, 139La, 140Ce, 143Nd, 145Nd, 146Nd, 147Sm, 153Eu, 157Gd, 163Dy, 166Er, 172Yb, 232Th, 238U. Internal reference mass 44Ca and CaO abundance measured by electron microprobe were used for concentration calculations. A typical signal acquisition started by collecting a background signal for 30 s, which was followed by a laser firing of 70 s or less depending on the thickness of the melt inclusion. The NIST 610 glass was used as an external standard (Gagnon et al., 2008). The glasses NIST 612 and BCR-2G (Gao et al., 2002) were also analyzed to check the accuracy and precision of the analyses. We found a good agreement between SIMS and LA-ICPMS measurements. Due to the abundance of counts available for the LA-ICPMS technique, the in-run precision was significantly better for the LA-ICPMS measurements. We reanalyzed all the melt inclusion by LA-ICPMS and SIMS 3f data are excluded from further discussion.

4. Results

4.1. Element abundances

In a total alkali-silica classification diagram (big symbols in Fig. 3), the melt inclusions range in composition from alkali basalts to trachybasalt to tephrite. The major element concentrations in the melt inclusions generally plot at the low SiO2 end of the lava composition suite of each volcano, sometimes extending the field of the lava compositions toward more primitive compositions, and are comparable to other olivine-hosted melt inclusion literature data from the same volcanoes (small symbols in Fig. 3). The Aci Castello melt inclusions have low (Na2O + K2O) and low K2O values (< 1.5 wt.%) relative to the 2002 Etna melt inclusions. The high K2O (â‰ˆ 2 wt.%) of E1 and E2 is actually a characteristic of Etna lavas erupted since 1974 (MÃ©trich et al., 2004). Previous studies have shown that olivine-hosted melt inclusions from Aci Castello include transitional basalt to alkalic basalt compositions (Kamenetsky and Clocchiatti, 1996, Clocchiatti et al., 1998). Our melt inclusions belong to the transitional group (Fig. 3a). Major element concentrations of the melt inclusions from the Aeolian Islands (Stromboli, Sommata and Alicudi) are also within the range described by other olivine-hosted melt inclusion compositions from the same volcanoes (Fig. 3b; Vaggelli et al., 1993, MÃ©trich et al., 2001, Massare et al., 2002, Bertagnini et al., 2003, Schiano et al., 2004). The Sommata melt inclusions have major element concentrations clustered around 4 wt.% total alkalis (Fig. 3b). Note that some silica-undersaturated melt inclusions from Alicudi and La Sommata (Table 1) display high CaO contents, up to 15.7 wt.%, which have been interpreted as reflecting participation of non-peridotitic lithologies in their sources (Schiano et al., 2000, Schiano et al., 2004). The total alkali contents increase from Alicudi, through Sommata, to Stromboli.

The back arc Marsili and Vavilov melt inclusions display relatively low K2O concentrations (< 1.5 wt.%; Fig. 3a and Table 1). The Ustica melt inclusions have high alkali concentrations (K2O + Na2O > 5 wt.%; Fig. 3a), similar to Etna melt inclusions, thus supporting the contention that magmatism of a Na-alkaline nature dominates the two volcanoes (e.g. Schiano et al., 2001, Schiano et al., 2004).

4.2. Volatile element concentrations

Melt inclusions display variable concentrations of total dissolved volatiles, from 0 to 4.3 wt.% based on the difference of total oxides from 100%. This range is similar to the total volatiles directly measured by SIMS (from 0.6 to 4.9 wt.%). The volatile contents of melt inclusions extend well beyond the ranges obtained for lavas of MORB and OIB tectonic settings (e.g., 0.04â€“0.50 and 0.3â€“0.1.5 wt.% H2O, for MORB and OIB repectively, based on our data compilation: see caption of Fig. 4 for the references used). Concentrations of F, S, and Cl in the melt inclusions are in the range of 268â€“1475, 604â€“3128, and 459â€“3579 ppm, respectively. Undegassed F and Cl concentrations observed in these melt inclusions are higher than those of primitive MORB (50â€“160 ppm F and 1â€“45 ppm Cl) and comparable to those of OIB (800â€“2800 ppm F and 200â€“1400 ppm Cl) (Fig. 4; Edmond et al., 1979, Dixon and Clague, 2001, Lassiter et al., 2002, Saal et al., 2002, Oppenheimer, 2004, Workman et al., 2006, Shaw et al., 2010). Because concentrations of CO2 and H2O are likely to have been modified by pre-entrapment degassing (CO2) and post-entrapment processes (H2O), their abundances do not reflect their primitive characters or source mantle characteristics and therefore will not be discussed further. On the contrary, F and Cl concentrations in the melt inclusions from Etna (and Aci Castello) can be considered representative of those of the undegassed magma since their entrapment pressures, as estimated previously by Spilliaert et al. (2006a), are higher than the exsolution pressure of F and Cl. They can thus fingerprint the volatile primitive composition of the melt inclusions (e.g. Le Voyer et al., 2010).

Based on their S/Cl ratios, olivine-hosted melt inclusions from the 2002 Etna eruption have been classified into two groups (Fig. 5; Spilliaert et al., 2006b), one with high S/Cl (â‰ˆ 2) and the other with low S/Cl (â‰ˆ 0.25; Spilliaert et al., 2006b, Collins et al., 2009). The low S/Cl, high K2O group is interpreted as the result of a more extensive exsolution of S (starts at higher pressures, â‰ˆ 150 MPa) associated with slower magma rise (Spilliaert et al., 2006b). Our samples represent both groups and thus it is difficult to draw many inferences concerning primary S contents. We have one Etna melt inclusion from each group (S/Cl = 1.85 and S/Cl = 0.36) and the Aci Castello melt inclusions have intermediate S/Cl of 1.3 and 1.7.

The other melt inclusions from this study have S/Cl values that are intermediate between the two groups from Etna (Stromboli: 0.6, Sommata: 0.6â€“0.7, Alicudi: 0.85, Marsili: 0.7â€“1.2, Vavilov: 1.5 and Ustica: 0.4â€“0.9). The S abundances of melt inclusions depend on the temperature, pressure, oxygen fugacity and iron content of the source, and presence or absence of sulfide residues (Lassiter et al., 2002, Saal et al., 2002). Therefore sulfur concentrations in melt inclusions are not simple diagnostic features of different mantle sources. The interpretation of S abundances is quite complex and beyond the scope of our study.

4.3. Pb isotope compositions

Nineteen olivine-hosted melt inclusions were analyzed for Pb isotopes. As illustrated in Fig. 6, they display a large range of Pb isotope ratios, 207Pb/206Pb and 208Pb/206Pb are strongly correlated and our data encompass those previously obtained for South Tyrrhenian whole rocks. More importantly, they extend to slightly more extreme Pb isotope values, thus giving additional information on the mantle source components involved in melting processes beneath the region. For the recent Etna sample (2002 lava), the 207Pb/206Pb isotope variations of the melt inclusions overlap and extend those of the whole rocks (from 0.778 Â± 0.001 to 0.820 Â± 0.002 for melt inclusions, relative to 0.7906 to 0.7929 for whole rocks from the 2002 eruption; Viccaro and Cristofolini, 2008). The melt inclusions from Aci Castello sample (early Etna) display more clustered 207Pb/206Pb values between 0.802 Â± 0.003 and 0.811 Â± 0.005. They represent intermediate Pb isotope compositions between Etna's most extreme melt inclusion and whole rock compositions (Fig. 6).

Isotope compositions of the other melt inclusions from the Aeolian arc volcanoes vary from low 207Pb/206Pb at Sommata (from 0.794 to 0.806) to high values at Stromboli and Alicudi (from 0.818 to 0.861). The 207Pb/206Pb values are consistent with Sommata and Stromboli whole rock (Fig. 6, small gray triangles and small gray diamonds, respectively), and melt inclusion data (Schiavi et al., 2011; not shown on Fig. 6).

In our melt inclusions 206Pb/204Pb varies from 18.10 Â± 0.04 to 20.16 Â± 0.13 (2Ïƒ) and 208Pb/204Pb varies from 38.05 Â± 0.08 to 40.53 Â± 0.67 (2Ïƒ) (Table 2).

5. Discussion

5.1. Mantle heterogeneity and the source of the volcanoes

On a 208Pb/206Pb versus 207Pb/206Pb diagram (Fig. 6), all data plot within the elongated diamond shape (the mantle trapezium) delimited by the four extreme mantle endmembers defined on the basis of Srâ€“Ndâ€“Pb isotope data (EMI, EMII, DMM, HIMU; following the isotopic taxonomy of Hart et al., 1992). They display a linear array from the center of the mantle trapezium towards the HIMU corner. Their isotopic compositons are generally consistent with previously published whole rock compositions.

It is immediately apparent that the Etna melt inclusions (including Aci Castello) cover most of the Pb isotope variations of Etna whole-rock data. Furthermore, Pb isotope compositions of Aci Castello melt inclusions plot within the range of those from the present-day Etna melt inclusions. Hence, the early-Etna represented by Aci Castello does not appear as an endmember. This contrasting Pb isotope composition between Aci Castello melt inclusions and 2002 Etna melt inclusions could represent the presence of a heterogeneous mantle, but more data is needed to confirm this. For instance, the E1 melt inclusion shows an evolved major element composition compared to other melt inclusions reported for the 2002 Etna flow. Together the Pb compositions of two studied melt inclusions E1 (in which we fitted three probe spots for three analyses, because the melt inclusion was big enough) and E2 define the two extremities of this flow (Fig. 6).

One sample, from Alicudi (A1A), deviate slightly toward DMM from the Pbâ€“Pb isotopic arrays defined by the bulk of the melt inclusion data. With the exception of this sample, the end of the Pb isotope linear trend approaches a mid point between the DMM and EMII endmembers. This illustrates that DMM alone cannot be the endmember of the source of Etna magmas. The magma source represented by this Pb isotope composition must be a mixture of DMM with EMII. HIMUâ€“DMMâ€“EMII mixing adequately explains the observed Pb isotope variations for melt inclusions as well as whole rocks. In this case, significant participation of EMI, is unnecessary. Alternatively, the 206Pb normalized data could be interpreted as showing a simple linear trend implying a two component mixture of HIMU and EMI (Fig. 6). Because HIMU and EMI are commonly attributed to small volume heterogeneities of the mantle, volumetrically smaller than the depleted mantle or FOZO, it seems geodynamically less plausible to consider direct mixing of two such smaller mantle heterogeneities without DMM or FOZO to explain the magma composition of the entire South Tyrrhenian region. A large mantle matrix such as DMM or FOZO is more likely involved. In any case, our preferred scenario is a mixing of HIMUâ€“DMMâ€“EMII, favoring the role of subarc mantle and subducted basaltic crust. Other three component mixing models involving FOZO, such as HIMUâ€“FOZOâ€“EMI, would not be resolvable. These conclusions of HIMUâ€“DMMâ€“EMII mixing are in good agreement with the hypotheses based on Pb isotope variations of whole rocks from Italian volcanoes, which have been used to propose mixing between HIMU-type mantle and (i) a DMM like mantle (D'Antonio et al., 1996, Gasperini et al., 2002) or (ii) a FOZO-like mantle (Peccerillo et al., 2004). The definitive identification of the FOZO component, regarded as entrained lower mantle (Hart et al., 1992), requires the full set of Pbâ€“Srâ€“Nd isotope data. We do not have this set of data and since our melt inclusion data project toward a point between FOZO and DMM, they are inadequate to identify the potential contribution of the FOZO component. Therefore, DMM is proposed as the main mantle matrix.

Our measurements of Pb isotope compositions for the Ustica melt inclusions (207Pb/206Pb = 0.805 Â± 0.004 and 0.811 Â± 0.003) plot within the variation of Etna lavas. The trace element characteristics of melt inclusions from Ustica Island reflect their derivation from an upwelling-enriched intraplate mantle source (maybe modified by subduction-related components; Trua et al., 2003), similar to what is found in Mount Etna and the nearby Iblean Mountains (Fig. 7; Schiano et al., 2004). Furthermore, the erupted lavas of Etna and Ustica display Na-alkaline compositions. Pb isotope compositions of the Ustica melt inclusions are within the range of the Etna values, and therefore our data suggest that Ustica samples were formed by mixing of the same components as for Etna. Two main processes could account for this multiple-source interaction beneath a single volcano: i) the Wâ€“SW limit of the Ionian slab is potentially located beneath Ustica and Mount Etna, thus allowing eruption of intermediate lavas between HIMU-like magmas and subduction-derived magmas; and ii) the rollback motion of the lithospheric slab that is subducting below the Tyrrhenian sea provides a sideways suction of enriched material from beneath the African plate (Gvirtzman and Nur, 1999).

In the Aeolian arc, it is proposed, based on a smooth increase of the 87Sr /86Sr of lavas from west to east, that a higher proportion of subducted crustal components (fluids + sediment melts) is added to the eastern Aeolian mantle wedge. For example, studies on lavas identified sediment-derived metasomatism in the magma source of Stromboli (U-Th data; DeAstis et al., 2000, Francalanci et al., 2007). Moreover, the radiogenic Pb isotope values of whole rocks from Stromboli (< 100 ky) were derived from metasomatizing fluids (or supercritical liquids) from the subducted altered basalt of the Ionian plate (Tommasini et al., 2007). Our Stromboli melt inclusions also show radiogenic Pb. However, the Ionian ocean crust is not old enough to develop the radiogenic Pb signature found here. The Pb isotope compositions of Stromboli (and Sommata) plot along the same mixing line as those for Etna and Ustica in a graph of 207Pb/206Pb versus 208Pb/206Pb (Fig. 6). Therefore, beneath Stromboli, the slab-derived metasomatic component must mix with a HIMU-like mantle (see discussion Section 5.3). As for the source of La Sommata, constraints from Srâ€“Ndâ€“Pb or Uâ€“Th on the lavas suggest a mantle wedge metasomatized to a small extent by sediments, and to a greater extent by aqueous fluids, both derived from the subducted oceanic crust (DeAstis et al., 2000, Francalanci et al., 2007).

The melt inclusions sampled from the back-arc volcanism are represented by Marsili and Vavilov. Except for 48A1, the 207Pb/206Pb isotope compositions range from 0.817 to 0.829. In Fig. 6, they plot in between the enriched (EMII) and depleted mantle (DMM) components (Fig. 6; in agreement with conclusions drawn from Vavilov lava studies; Gasperini et al., 2002, Trua et al., 2010). The enriched component (EMII-type) was proposed to be a depleted Southern Tyrrhenian mantle wedge variably contaminated by addition of subduction material (ODP Leg 107, Site 655; Beccaluva et al., 1990, Gasperini et al., 2002), and/or an OIB-like mantle source, similar to the source of the Etna and Ustica lavas (Trua et al., 2010). It should be noted that one Vavilov sample (48A1) shows a significant Sr enrichment compared to Nd (an element with a similar compatibility in spinel peridotite, Fig. 7b), an indication of plagioclase, and thus possibly crustal, assimilation and therefore represents the â€œcrustal signatureâ€. Although the melt is included in olivine, we conclude that its Pb isotope ratios reflect lower crust assimilation instead of a source composition. The crust below Vavilov basin is underlain by a 10 km thick magmatic unit (Rehault et al., 1987), significantly thinner than typical continental crust. Crustal contamination by a plagioclase-rich magmatic lithology, such as gabbro, is consistent with the Sr enrichment.

5.2. Primary volatile abundances inferred from F/Nd and Cl/Nb

Models of source mixing processes can be constrained by combining variations of isotopic compositions and volatile abundances, because the heterogeneous asthenospheric mantle components are drier compared to subduction-related components (sediments, and altered oceanic crust). As stressed earlier, uncertainty in the estimation of the exact primary source H2O and CO2 abundances limits the use of these elements for source characterization. In addition, volatile abundance must be determined on the same material on which isotopic composition is measured. The F and Cl halogen contents in the primitive melt inclusions characterize undegassed, pre-eruptive abundances. By comparing F and Cl contents of primitive melt inclusions from different geodynamic settings, we infer relative enrichment of F and Cl, and thus potentially of all volatile elements, of the source mantle.

Trace element ratios of F/Nd are quite constant in melt inclusions and glasses from MORB and OIB, with an average value of 21 Â± 5 (Fig. 8; Workman et al., 2006), and there is no F/Nd fractionation during melting. This constancy is interpreted as being due to the similarity in bulk partition coefficients for this element pair during mantle melting. Experimentally determined partition coefficients of F between melt and mantle minerals support this claim (Dalou et al., 2011). Hence, F/Nd ratios in the melts are presumed to be identical to ratios of these elements in the mantle source. Furthermore, since F abundance in seawater (1.3 ppm; e.g. Michard, 1989) is significantly lower than that found in rocks, the F/Nd ratios of bulk continent and pelagic sediments remain close to 21, and F concentrations are of the same order as those of MORB (F/Nd(bulk continental crust) = 28, Rudnick and Gao, 2003; F/Nd(pelagic clay) = 24, Li, 1991). Carbonates have high F/Nd (40â€“80, values taken from continental carbonates; Gao et al., 1998) but F concentration is in the range of 500 ppm, not significantly higher than fresh MORB (100â€“600 ppm). Therefore, there is no significant F reservoir associated with subduction zone input which can change F/Nd significantly. Therefore we assume that the crust entering the subduction zone has F/Nd â‰ˆ 21. Similarly, Cl/Nb is used here as a source characterizing ratio, because these two highly incompatible elements do not fractionate significantly during peridotite melting (Dalou et al., 2011). We have delimited the dry mantle Cl/Nb values to be between 5 and 35 on the basis of MORBâ€“OIB data (Fig. 8).

High Cl/Nb compared to dry mantle is the result of H2O-rich metasomatism of a mantle wedge by a subducting slab flux, because of the high solubility of Cl combined with the elevated Cl abundance in altered oceanic crust. In agreement with previous observations of H2O abundance in melt inclusions (volatile-rich magmas from Etna have already been reported in melt inclusions from historic lavas; MÃ©trich et al., 1993), Aeolian arc magmas are higher in Cl/Nb than Etnaâ€“Ustica samples, and the Etnaâ€“Ustica Cl/Nb ratios are within the range of the MORBâ€“OIB variation. This is consistent with the notion that some Etnaâ€“Ustica magmas are mainly derived from a dry asthenospheric mantle and/or from dehydrated recycled material. Using this logic, and if the fluids have similar Cl concentrations, the intermediate Cl/Nb values of Stromboli between Sommata and Etna could indicate a smaller contribution of fluids derived from altered oceanic crust in the Stromboli source. An alternative explanation for the difference between Sommata, Etna and Stromboli could be the heterogeneity of the fluid compositions (Fig. 8).

The F/Nd of Etna melt inclusions varies from 13 to 25. The F/Nd values found in the Aeolian arc samples (Stromboli, 27â€“30, and Sommata, 32â€“33) are higher than those of Etna and the MORBâ€“OIB range. Therefore, high F/Nd must be an indication of mantle metasomatism in subduction zones. It should be noted that the Nd concentration of nearly all of our melt inclusions is higher than that of typical MORB melt inclusions; high F/Nd is therefore due to higher F concentration rather than depletion of Nd. Furthermore, high F/Nd ratios are systematically found in many arc melt inclusions (e.g. Le Voyer et al., 2010), though the mechanism for fractionating F from Nd has not been identified yet.

A general positive correlation between Cl/Nb and F/Nd is present among our melt inclusions (Fig. 8). Assuming simultaneous increase of Cl/Nb and F/Nd is only achieved by an input of fluid (or melt, or supercritical fluid) derived from the subducting Ionian slab, Sommata magma should be the richest in the slab component. It is expected to have the highest primary H2O content (in fact water abundance is 4.21 wt.% H2O; Table 2). On the contrary, the low Cl/Nb values of Etna and Ustica are comparable to the range for MORBâ€“OIB, suggesting a dry-mantle source. The lowest F/Nd (13 and 15; Table 2) correspond to Etnean/early-Etnean melt inclusions with the lowest 207Pb/206Pb (Fig. 6; 0.778 and 0.802, respectively; Table 2). These F/Nd values are slightly lower than the typical mantle value (21 Â± 5). Because nearly all primitive arc magmas plot on the right-hand side of F/Nd = 21, we would expect that oceanic crust recycled into deep mantle should plot on the left of the F/Nd divide of 21, as indicated by the arrow (Fig. 8). The comparison of melt inclusions in the F/Nd versus Cl/Nb systematics effectively distinguishes recycled dehydrated material from the other hydrated mantle melt inclusions (Fig. 8).

5.3. Nature of the recycled material

What exactly is the nature of the magma sources beneath southern Italy? From the systematics of the F/Nd against Pb isotope ratio plot (Fig. 9), it is possible to characterize the volatile abundance of three major magma sources corresponding to the end-members of the melt inclusion arrays. While we have chosen F/Nd to characterize source volatile abundances, other ratios involving volatile elements (e.g. Cl/Nb), as well as certain ratios of non-volatile elements (e.g. Ba/Nb), yield the same systematics. Here, Sommata melt inclusions represent a fluid-rich arc component (termed 1 in Fig. 9) with high F/Nd (35) and moderate Pb isotopic compositions (0.798, 2.01 and 19.5 for 207Pb/206Pb, 208Pb/206Pb and 206Pb/204Pb, respectively). Consequently, this arc magma source is characterized by high Cl/Nb (â‰ˆ 750; Table 2, because of the combined effect of Cl enrichment and strong Nb depletion), and low Nb/La (â‰ˆ 0.22) (Fig. 7; Table 3). On the contrary the extreme Etna magmas represent a component (termed 2 in Fig. 9) that has F/Nd = 11 and 207Pb/206Pb = 0.780 (1.97 and 19.9 for 208Pb/206Pb and 206Pb/204Pb, respectively), with Cl/Nb â‰ˆ 20 and Nb/La â‰ˆ 1.0. There is no direct mixing trend between these two entities. Instead, the third component with moderately high 207Pb/206Pb (0.832) explains the apparent presence of two binary mixing relationships (F/Nd = 24.5, and Cl/Nb â‰ˆ 80). One melt inclusion of Alicudi shows a Pb isotope composition indistinguishable from typical depleted MORB mantle, but with high F/Nd and Cl/Nb values (termed 4 in Fig. 9). Although more melt inclusions from Alicudi are needed to establish the presence of this entity, especially more Pb-isotope measurements, other authors have measured high F/Nd (> 35) and high Cl/Nb (> 400) in Alicudi olivine-hosted melt inclusions (SorbadÃ¨re pers. com., 2012). We interpret this source characteristics as representing the metasomatism of a typical depleted mantle by a fluid rich in F and Cl but not in Pb. Although this interpretation relies on only one melt inclusion it is consistent with the proposal based on whole rock data that the Alicudi source was modified by fluids or melts coming from an oceanic slab, with little or no involvement from the subducted sediments (Peccerillo et al., 2004). This event modified trace element signatures but did not significantly alter isotopic compositions (Peccerillo et al., 2004).Globally, the Pb isotopic compositions in Fig. 6 can be explained with a binary mixing model with two components, not three (see linear spread between Etna and Alicudi in Fig. 6; shown as components 2 and 4 in Fig. 9). Alicudi sample A1A, component 4, represents a DMMâ€“EMII mixture rich in DMM. We think the variation of F/Ndâ€“Pbâ€“Pb isotopes among the Southern Italian melt inclusions (Fig. 9) reflects mixing between a slightly modified depleted mantle (component 3, DMMâ€“EMII mixture; Fig. 9) and a radiogenic (component 2, HIMU-like; Fig. 9) mantle component expressed in Pb isotope space, superposed by slab-derived metasomatic components (component 1; Fig. 9) traced by F/Nd. The fluid-rich slab components are expected to transport far less Pb and Nd than F and Cl. This explains the weak â€œfluid-Pbâ€ imprinting of Aeolian arc samples.

âŽ

This melt inclusion has a Sr anomaly (Sr/Nd)PM > 10 suggesting plagioclase assimilation and is discarded from the following discussion.

â—†

U1 was so small that the spot of the LA-ICP-MS analysis was bigger than the inclusion. Trace element concentrations were corrected for dilution by a constant correction factor on the basis of ion probe trace element measurements.

Finally, we note that this HIMU-like radiogenic Pb source is synonymous with the ITalian Enriched Mantle (ITEM) defined by Bell et al. (2005). The volatile element ratios we inferred for this component rule out any hydrothermally altered recycled oceanic crust as for ITEM because such crust would have both high F/Nd and Cl/Nb (> 90 and > 1000, respectively; Lassiter et al., 2002). Here, melt inclusions with radiogenic Pb have systematically low F/Nd (< 21) and low K/U (Lassiter et al., 2003, Lassiter, 2004). Furthermore, because mantle melting processes do not change F/Nd, few mantle processes produce F/Nd < 21. Therefore, the most plausible explanation may be that low F/Nd results from slab dehydration processes. The fluid, coming from the slab, metasomatizes and raises the F/Nd of the mantle wedge. The HIMU endmember is derived from a high U/Pb (Î¼) lithology isolated for up to two billion years resulting in the generation of a highly radiogenic Pb isotopic composition (Hart and Zindler, 1989); it is considered to represent old subducted crust that resides in the mantle long enough and resurfaces predominantly in plume-derived magmas. The HIMU-like Etna component cannot be derived from the subducted Ionian crust, because it would take more than 500 Myrs to create a source with Pb characteristics consistent with those of Etna, even assuming a high Î¼ value for the oceanic crust (for example Î¼ = 20, initial 206Pb/204Pb = 18.38, 207Pb/204Pb = 15.5 is used for this calculation. Note: with a subduction rate of 1 cmÂ·yrâˆ’ 1, it will take less than 100 Myr to reach the lower mantle). Our results identify the presence of a volatile-poor, old, recycled, oceanic crust in the deep mantle rising beneath Etnean volcanoes, Aci Castello sharing the same source as modern Etna.

6. Conclusions

  • (1)

    Enrichment of volatile elements in magma souce regions is effectively indentified by volatile element/trace element ratios, such as F/Nd, and Cl/Nd, measured in melt inclusions. Since F and Cl are late degassing elements, these elements are preferred over H2O and CO2, which are prone to various pre- and post-entrapment modifications.

  • (2)

    Pb isotope compositions found in melt inclusions are within the range of variation defined by whole rock Pb data. No new extreme values have been found among melt inclusions.

  • (3)

    We conclude that Pb isotope and volatile element concentration measurements in melt inclusions allowed us to confirm that there is a dry HIMU-like radiogenic Pb source under South Tyrrhenian volcanoes. Using the F/Ndâ€“Cl/Nb systematics, we rule out the presence of recently subducted, altered oceanic crust for this radiogenic Pb source. The low F/Nd of this radiogenic component results from (i.e. is the residue of) slab dehydration processes.

  • Carbon and oxygen isotope analysis of CO<inf>2</inf> trapped in silicate minerals

    2022, Chemical Geology
    Citation Excerpt :

    In contrast, melt inclusions (MIs) are small droplets of magma (1â€“100 Î¼m in diameter) trapped inside minerals such as olivine, pyroxene, plagioclase, quartz and spinel grown at crust or mantle depths, potentially trapping undegassed CO2 that is the counterpart of volatiles associated with magma eruption (Sorby, 1858; Roedder, 1979; Sobolev and Danyushevsky, 1994; Danyushevsky et al., 1997; Danyushevsky et al., 2002; Kamenetsky et al., 2002; Kent, 2008; Aster et al., 2016). Olivine is the most common mineral in the upper mantle and represents the most primitive crystal in basaltic magmas (Mattey et al., 1994; Scarsi, 2000; Martelli et al., 2004; Sapienza et al., 2005; Gurenko et al., 2011; Rose-Koga et al., 2012; Barry et al., 2014; MÃ©trich and Deloule, 2014; Grozeva et al., 2020). After CO2-rich MIs are trapped in olivine deep in the magmatic system, they remain shielded and retain their primary carbon isotopic composition (Kent, 2008; Wallace et al., 2015; Gennaro et al., 2017; Blank and Brooker, 2018).

  • Determination of halogens in geological reference materials using neutron irradiation noble gas mass spectrometry

    2021, Chemical Geology
    Citation Excerpt :

    Halogens are continuously expelled from the mantle via volcanic activity and are concentrated on the surface of the Earth, but they are simultaneously transported into the mantle at subduction zones (Barnes et al., 2018; Broadley et al., 2016; Kendrick et al., 2011, 2017; Kobayashi et al., 2017; Portnyagin et al., 2007; Rose-Koga et al., 2012; Straub and Layne, 2003; Sumino et al., 2010; Wade et al., 2006). Contrasting halogen concentration coupled with distinct compositions among different reservoirs make the halogens powerful tracers of various geological processes such as global volatile circulation (Barnes et al., 2018; Broadley et al., 2016; Kendrick et al., 2011, 2017; Kobayashi et al., 2017, 2019; Portnyagin et al., 2007; Rose-Koga et al., 2012; Straub and Layne, 2003; Sumino et al., 2010; Wade et al., 2006). Halogens also play an important role in transporting metal elements.
